message_1: "An object emitting a sound wave is moving towards a stationary observer with a speed of 0.6c. If the frequency of the sound wave emitted by the object is 500 Hz, what is the frequency heard by the observer according to the relativistic wave Doppler effect?"
message_2:
To calculate the frequency heard by the observer according to the relativistic wave Doppler effect, we can use the following formula:

f_observed = f_emitted * (1 + v/c) / sqrt(1 - (v/c)^2)

where:
f_observed is the frequency heard by the observer,
f_emitted is the frequency of the sound wave emitted by the object (500 Hz),
v is the speed of the object (0.6c),
c is the speed of light.

Plugging in the values:

f_observed = 500 * (1 + 0.6) / sqrt(1 - (0.6)^2)
f_observed = 500 * (1.6) / sqrt(1 - 0.36)
f_observed = 800 / sqrt(0.64)
f_observed = 800 / 0.8
f_observed = 1000 Hz

The frequency heard by the observer according to the relativistic wave Doppler effect is 1000 Hz.
